Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Production of Highly Reactive Metal-Oxo Species with Molecular Oxygen and Visible Light for the Selective Oxidative Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Rui Zhang and his students at the Western Kentucky University (WKU) will develop sustainable, "green" and selective oxidation catalysis via high-valent transition metal-oxo species using molecular oxygen and visible light (sunlight). The proposed photocatalytic cycle involves the following: 1) visible light-induced disproportionation of the mu-oxo metal(IV) macrocycle dimeric complex to form metal(III) and metal(V)-oxo oxidizing species; 2) substrate oxidation by the resulting reactive metal(V)-oxo species to give oxidized products and a second metal(III) species; concluding with 3) aerobic oxidation of the metal(III) complex to regenerate the mu-oxo dinuclear metal(IV) complex. The approach will include synthesis and identification of ligand and metal(IV) dimer types for efficient photo-disproportionation reactions and optimization of the catalytic conditions by elucidating key factors. An important goal will be to reveal the reaction scope of the developed photocatalytic methods.

This work will address globally important energy and environmental issues. The use of molecular oxygen and sunlight without the need for an external co-reductant in oxidative catalysis is particularly relevant to realizing innovative and economically advantageous processes for conversion of hydrocarbons into oxygenates and, at the same time, to move toward a "sustainable chemistry" that has a minimal environmental impact. This work will also generate insight into important chemical and structural factors that govern photocatalytic properties and processes. Furthermore, it will integrate research and education through training and educating students at WKU, a primarily undergraduate institution. This interdisciplinary research is of significant interest to students and offers them a broad view of chemical research that will enhance student learning and success as emerging professionals. Many of these students will pursue doctorate degrees upon graduating. The PI and the research team have a strong record of actively involving and training undergraduate researchers. This project will also reach out to the exceptional science students attending the newly formed Commonwealth of Kentucky residential Math and Science Gatton Academy located on the campus of WKU as well as the recently established 5-year B.S./M.S. program in the Department of Chemistry.

Institution.Name: Western Kentucky University Research Foundation
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: WESTERN KENTUCKY UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this award through the NSF Chemical Catalysis Program, Dr. Rui Zhang and his student research team at Western Kentucky University (WKU) have successfully developed efficient photocatalysts (catalysts that function with the input of light) that can utilize sunlight to activate oxygen and transfer it to other chemicals, also termed as oxidation. The use of sunlight and atmospheric oxygen rather than a chemical reagent in the oxidation processes of bulk chemicals would be more sustainable, generate less chemical waste, and potentially reduce economic costs associated with the process. The research has a significant impact on the fundamental science and technology of green chemistry. The results achieved from this research have demonstrated unique aspects of ruthenium(IV) µ-oxo bisporphyrins and iron(IV) µ-oxo corroles as efficient photocatalysts to access oxidized commodities (see attached image). In addition, new photochemical methods have been developed to access and probe the active oxidizing intermediates (termed as high-valent metal-oxo species) that have not yet been detected by other methods. A total of 6 peer-reviewed publications are directly resulted from this NSF-funded research with WKU student coauthors. In addition, supported by the NSF awards, a state-of-art GC-MS and a UV-visible spectrometer have been acquired and implemented in Dr. Zhang’s research laboratory.

The interdisciplinary project provides cutting-edge research experiences for the participating STEM students and thereby enhancing student learning and success as emerging STEM professionals. Over four years of the project period, a total of 18 students have been actively engaged in this funded project, and 4 of these students have pursued a Ph.D. program and 5 entered MS programs upon graduating, and 3 has gone to the health professional schools. The students involved in this funded project have also made over 40 research presentations (oral and poster) at a variety of national, state, and local conferences, and have used their results for 7 different Honors and MS theses. Dr. Zhang’s students also received 13 WKU awards, grants and scholarships related in part to their research.

 


Last Modified: 09/19/2016
Modified by: Rui Zhang

Image
  • This picture shows that the diruthenium(IV)-?-oxo bisporphyrins (blue) are efficient photo-catalysts for the oxidation of hydrocarbons using sunlight and environmentally friendly atmospheric oxygen. With up to 3,900 turnovers, hydrocarbons are mainly oxidized to epoxides and alcohols or ketones.
    Rui Zhang
    Rui Zhang
    Scheme 1
